- 8 -
CNAC for not bringing out more Government officials and less CHAC
staff.
My answer
to that was that we brought every official that we
Neprud, who
persuado officials to come
or even to the Peninsula Hotel
where we could get them, which is perfectly true.
Except for one
Chinese general, who came to Kaitak himself, I do not believe we
would have evacuated any unless we had dofinitely made all the ar-
rangements and got them to the Airport.
Thisk or
course, was due
partly to the fact that no one expected the situation to
worsen so
sidering.
got in and out of fongkong with perfoct safety on Wednesday and
Thursday; however, it is hardly fair to say this since I was not
there.
On
Thursday I called on 51r Archibald Clark Kerr, the Brit-
1sh Ambassador to China, and he sent a rush message to the Governor
of Hongkong,
requesting permission for ChAC to
come in that night.
Later he got a reply from the Governor authorizing two flights be-
tween 9 and 12 p.m.
We sent further messages to Hongkong requesting
permission to make more flights the following night but got no reply.
At 4 o'clock that afternoon, two of our DC-3's, flown by Pilots
McDonaid and Higgs, left Chungking for Hongkong to make the two
flights authorized. About one hour out of Hongkong they recoived a
message from Moss telling
them that arrangements had been cancelled
and instructing them not to come to Hongkong•
No reason was given.
McDonald and Higgs then changed their course
to Namyung, where they
landed and picked up members of our staff left there on previous
flights cut of longkong and returned to Chungking•
That was our
last effort to get into Hongkong•
On
Thursday we got word the Japanese had raided Namyung
heavily and had repeatedly machine-gunned our DC-3 at low altitudes.
The engines were ruined and so were
the props.
Most of the instru-
ments wero shot to pieces, the tires, control lines, hydraulic lines,
landing gear and gas tanks.
Vie have
dismantled it and got it off
the field
several miles.
We plan to build sneds over the fusilage
and wings and rebuild it. It will take a long time and we must have
lots of parts
fron
the States.
We can do the rebuilding in five or
six months.
I can't even guess when we can
get tho
parts from the
States, but one of these days me will have it back in service.
I would like to say here that I have since criticized my-
sell severely for leaving Schafer.
I feel very badly about it, but
at the time it seemed the best thing to do and there
did not seem to
be any increased danger.
Schafer's conduct throughout was splendid.
He is a good man and
could handle the situation very well.
I felt
perfectly satisfied in leaving everything to him, but I am sorry
now that I did.
For the last three days we have made flights every evening
to Namyung and back, bringing out supplies which have been evacuated
out of
Hongkong.
We are resuming our schedules to
the extent of
three times per week from Chungking to Kunming to Lashio and one of
these trips
to Lashio continues to Calcutta.
We make our first
flight to Calcutta on Thursday of this week (December 18th) •
I plan
to meet Sir Frederick Tys, Director of Air Civil of India, in
